questions.text: A 2-year-old child presents with watering of eyes with bilateral proptosis and photophobia. What may be the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Congenital glaucoma Children with congenital glaucoma mostly present with blepharospasm , photophobia , and lacrimation . Hazy cornea with blue sclera , as seen in the picture, further confirms the diagnosis.

Highyeild:

Important Signs:- Corneal signs : Corneal signs include its oedema, enlargement and Descemet's breaks. Corneal oedema - It is frequently the first sign which arouses suspicion Corneal enlargement- It occurs along with enlargement of globe-buphthalmos especially when the onset is before the age of 3yrs Haab's striae ( Tears and break in Descement's membrane )- These occur because Descement's membrane is less elastic than the corneal stroma. Tears are usually peripheral and concentric with the limbus .

Extraedge:

Pathogenesis Primary congenital glaucoma is due to failure or abnormal development of the trabecular meshwork Maldevelopment of trabeculae including:- The iridotrabecular junction (trabeculodysgenesis) is responsible for impaired aqueous outflow resulting in raised IOP. Trabeculodysgenesis is characterized by absence of the angle recess with iris having a flat or concave direct insertion into the surface. The iris may not completely separate from the corned that the angle remains closed by persistent embryonic tissue

Table:

#MANTRA

questions.text: The pair of spectacles shown in the picture below are used in:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bifocal glasses for presbyopia Bifocal eyeglasses have a distance vision prescription at the top of the lens and a near vision prescription at the lower part of the lens. Progressive eyeglass lenses provide that as well, plus a smooth progression of power between the two for viewing intermediate distances.

Highyeild:

CAUSES FOR PRESBYOPIA Uncorrected hypermetropia Premature sclerosis of crystalline lens Presenile weakness of ciliary muscle Chronic simple glaucoma

Extraedge:

Pathophysiology IN PRESBYOPIA:- ciliary muscle contraction ceases ⬇️ posterior zonular fibers pull the ciliary muscle backward ⬇️ increases tension on the zonular fires ⬇️ increase in lens diameter, decrease in lens thickness and a flattening of the anterior and posterior lens surface curvatures ⬇️ decrease in optical power

Table:

#MANTRA HYPEROPIA VERSUS PRESBYOPIA Is not a consequence of aging Is a consequence of aging Does not usually first occur after age 40 Usually occurs first from age 40 on Can occur from childhood or birth Does not usually occur from childhood Cause is unusual shaped eyeball, lens or cornea Not caused by unusual shaped eyeball, lens or cornea Not caused by hardening of lens and weakening of ciliary muscles over time Cause is hardening of lens and weakening of ciliary muscles over time

questions.text: What is the angle subtended by the topmost letter of Snellen’s chart at the nodal point of eye?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

50 min Angle subtended by the topmost letter of Snellen’s chart at 60 meters is 5 min of arc. Therefore, at 6 meters = 5 × 10 = 50 min.

Highyeild:

Results Of Snellens Chart:- Expressed as a ratio recorded as X / Y Where X is the testing distance and Y refers to the line containing the smallest letter that the patient identifies For example a patient has a visual acuity of 6/9

Extraedge:

Uses of visual acuity test To measure the patient’s progress visual acuity must be assessed at every presentation. Diagnostic tool Baseline data Measures progression of disease Evaluates treatment Legal requirement

Table:

#MANTRA

questions.text: What is the most common eye manifestation in Sturge–Weber syndrome?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Glaucoma Glaucoma is the most serious ocular manifestation in Sturge–Weber syndrome . 50% of patients develop glaucoma between infancy and later childhood. Symptoms may be:- large and cloudy eyes, photophobia, and It is related to:- AC malformations , high episcleral venous pressure, and changes in ocular hemodynamics. vascular malformations of conjunctiva, episclera, choroid, and retina.

Highyeild:

Sturge Weber Syndrome:- SKIN -> facial port-wine birthmark in the ophthalmic distribution of trigeminal nerve or in the maxillary distribution of trigeminal nerve EYES - glaucoma and visual field deficits BRAIN -› leptomeningeal angioma , seizures, hemiparesis/plegia, mental/ motor retardation, strokes or stroke-like episodes.

Extraedge:

ACUTE CONGESTIVE ANGLE CLOSURE GLAUCOMA Due to rapid ↑ in 10P Defined as: At least 2 of the following SYMPTOMS Ocular pain Nausea/ vomiting Hx of intermittent BOV with halos Plus 3 of the following SIGNS IOP > 21mmHg Conjunctival injection Corneal epithelial edema Mid-dilated non reactive pupil Shallower chamber in presence of occlusion

Table:

#MANTRA

questions.text: A patient came to AIIMS OPD with acute pain and watering from eye for 3 days. There was 3 x 2 mm ulcer on the cornea with ROLLED OUT margins and feathery and finger-like projections with minimal hypopyon. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Fungal With filamentary fungi the corneal lesions have a white/gray infiltrate with feathery borders. There might be satellite lesions with hypopyon and conjunctival injection as well as purulent secretions. Ulcers caused by yeast are plaque-like and slightly more defined, similar to bacterial keratitis.

Highyeild:

Signs Opacity in the cornea which will take up fluorescein stain as the epithelium will be abraded. Pupils will be constricted and sluggishly reactive due to irritation to the iris. This toxic reaction can produce hypopyon which will be sterile in bacterial ulcers. In fungal ulcer fungal hyphae may be present.

Extraedge:

Stages Stage of progressive infiltration Stage of active ulceration Stage of regression Stage of cicatrization

Table:

#MANTRA

questions.text: Below image signifies which of the following condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Oculomotor nerve palsy In complete third nerve palsy , the patient will have complete ptosis. The eye appears down and out when the lid is elevated . In isolated third nerve palsy, the functions of the fourth and sixth nerves can be demonstrated by normal intorsion and abduction respectively.

Highyeild:

Syndromes of Fascicular lesion Benedikt syndrome- Ipsilateral 3rd nerve palsy and contralateral extrapyramidal signs Weber syndrome- Ipsilateral 3rd nerve palsy and contralateral hemiparesis Nothnagel syndrome- Ipsilateral 3rd nerve palsy and cerebellar ataxia SIGNS Ptosis Abduction of globe Intorsion of the globe which increases on attempted down gaze Limitation of adduction Limitation of elevation Limitation of depression Dilated pupil with defective accommodation

Extraedge:

Causes of isolated 3rd nerve palsy Idiopathic - about 25% Vascular Hypertension & Diabetes - (commonly pupil sparing) Aneurysm - posterior communicating - artery at its junction with internal carotid artery Trauma - subdural hematoma with uncal herniation Miscellaneous SYMPTOMS Drooping of eyelid Binocular double vision Pain (may be present)

questions.text: Identify the marked layer in the given histology section:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Inner plexiform layer

Extraedge:

Central retinal artery occlusion-CRAO It is an obstruction of the circulation of the retina due to embolus and thrombosis . Caused by hypertension and arteriosclerosis . Commonly results in complete or permanent blindness. Signs:- Direct light reflex disappear indirect light reflex normal Retinal edema, cherry-red spot Retina artery narrowing, retinal hemorrhages Treatment:- Vasodilator (acetylcholine) dilate the spasm artery acetylsalicylic acid (aspirin) to prevent clot formation

Table:

#MANTRA
